articles.headline: Janet Yellen Speech Indicates Fed Will Rethink Interest-Rate Plans
articles.snippet: A previous assurance that rates would be raised “in the coming months” was dropped from a speech that Ms. Yellen gave on Monday.
articles.abstract: A previous assurance that rates would be raised “in the coming months” was dropped from a speech that Ms. Yellen gave on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The Federal Reserve, mindful of unexpectedly weak job growth last month, has abandoned hope of raising interest rates at its next meeting in June, but Fed officials say they are still thinking seriously about raising rates in July or September.

articles.headline: Iraqis Who Flee Fighting in Falluja Find Hardship and Hunger
articles.snippet: Survivors reach aid camps hungry, thirsty and scared, and their ordeals are not over: They are in the arms of a government without the resources to care for them.
articles.abstract: Survivors reach aid camps hungry, thirsty and scared, and their ordeals are not over: They are in the arms of a government without the resources to care for them.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMIRIYAT FALLUJA, Iraq — One of the Iraqi civilians who risked an escape from the sprawling battle for Falluja made it as far as the Euphrates River. He was there for all to see on Sunday morning: His body, tied to the side of a boat, bobbed in the muddy waters next to a rickety bridge that separates Baghdad from the violence of Anbar Province.

articles.headline: Kalashnikov, Maker of AK-47, Looks to Rebrand
articles.snippet: After American sanctions cut off one of its biggest markets, the Russian gun maker embarked on changes that executives say are yielding results.
articles.abstract: After American sanctions cut off one of its biggest markets, the Russian gun maker embarked on changes that executives say are yielding results.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A shipment of Kalashnikov rifles, popularly known as AK-47s, was destined for the United States when it was stopped and quickly rerouted to Venezuela. Washington had just slapped Moscow with sanctions over the Ukraine crisis, and the Russian gun maker Kalashnikov Kontsern suddenly found one of its biggest markets off limits.

articles.headline: Democrats Jump on Allies of Donald Trump in Judge Dispute
articles.snippet: A report that Mr. Trump urged his supporters to defend his criticisms of a judge’s Mexican heritage, and then rebuked his staff for having suggested otherwise, gave his rivals added ammunition.
articles.abstract: A report that Mr. Trump urged his supporters to defend his criticisms of a judge’s Mexican heritage, and then rebuked his staff for having suggested otherwise, gave his rivals added ammunition.
articles.lead_paragraph: Democratic leaders nationwide sought to exact a political price from Republican officials and candidates on Monday for continuing to support Donald J. Trump after his explosive remarks challenging the objectivity of judges with Mexican or Muslim backgrounds.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy, Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: National Amusements Alters Viacom Bylaws to Stymie Sale of Paramount
articles.snippet: The theater chain, through which Sumner Redstone controls his empire, said it wanted to ensure that any sale was part of a long-term strategy.
articles.abstract: The theater chain, through which Sumner Redstone controls his empire, said it wanted to ensure that any sale was part of a long-term strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Viacom, selling a stake in its Paramount film studio has become potentially more difficult — thanks to its controlling shareholder.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Emily Steel

articles.headline: Regulators Fear $1 Billion Coal Cleanup Bill
articles.snippet: Officials worry that failed coal companies will use bankruptcy courts to pay off debts to banks and hedge funds, leaving behind their environmental obligations.
articles.abstract: Officials worry that failed coal companies will use bankruptcy courts to pay off debts to banks and hedge funds, leaving behind their environmental obligations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Regulators are wrangling with bankrupt coal companies to set aside enough money to clean up Appalachia’s polluted rivers and mountains so that taxpayers are not stuck with the $1 billion bill.

articles.headline: Who Decides ‘Fair Value?’ In Dell’s Case, a Judge
articles.snippet: A court’s decision that Dell Inc. sold for $6 billion too little means that companies don’t simply have to find the highest bidder, but that a judge may deem what the price should be.
articles.abstract: A court’s decision that Dell Inc. sold for $6 billion too little means that companies don’t simply have to find the highest bidder, but that a judge may deem what the price should be.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Has Clinched Democratic Nomination, Survey Reports
articles.snippet: On the eve of the New Jersey and California primaries, an Associated Press survey of superdelegates indicated that Mrs. Clinton had gone over the top.
articles.abstract: On the eve of the New Jersey and California primaries, an Associated Press survey of superdelegates indicated that Mrs. Clinton had gone over the top.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton became the first woman to capture the presidential nomination of one of the country’s major political parties on Monday night, according to an Associated Press survey of Democratic superdelegates, securing enough of them to overcome a bruising challenge from Senator Bernie Sanders and turn to a brutal five-month campaign against Donald J. Trump.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Patrick Healy

articles.headline: Jobs Threatened by Machines: A Once ‘Stupid’ Concern Gains Respect
articles.snippet: The productivity figures may not reflect it yet, but new technology, with its robots and self-driving cars, seems more disruptive than technologies of the past.
articles.abstract: The productivity figures may not reflect it yet, but new technology, with its robots and self-driving cars, seems more disruptive than technologies of the past.
articles.lead_paragraph: They replaced horses, didn’t they? That’s how the late, great economist Wassily Leontief responded 35 years ago to those who argued technology would never really replace people’s work.

articles.headline: Lancôme Provokes Fury After Canceling a Concert in Hong Kong
articles.snippet: The French cosmetics company was accused of bending to China after dropping a concert by a singer who supported the pro-democracy Occupy movement.
articles.abstract: The French cosmetics company was accused of bending to China after dropping a concert by a singer who supported the pro-democracy Occupy movement.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When Lancôme organized a small concert in Hong Kong featuring a local Cantopop star, the company billed the event as “Made of Unstoppable Energy.”
articles.byline: By Amie Tsang and Alan Wong

articles.headline: Paul Ryan Calls Donald Trump’s Attack on Judge ‘Racist,’ but Still Backs Him
articles.snippet: Donald Trump’s attack on a Hispanic-American federal judge was “the textbook definition of a racist comment,” Mr. Ryan said.
articles.abstract: Donald Trump’s attack on a Hispanic-American federal judge was “the textbook definition of a racist comment,” Mr. Ryan said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker Paul D. Ryan, the nation’s highest-ranking Republican, on Tuesday called Donald J. Trump’s remarks about a Latino judge “racist,” an extraordinary indictment that generated a fresh wave of criticism and panic from other Republicans. By the end of the day, Mr. Trump was forced into a rare moment of damage control and said that his words had been “misconstrued.”
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer, Jonathan Martin and David M. Herszenhorn
